properties.name: Chapel
properties.hist: The chapel, designed by Kaija and Heikki Siren, is situated on the highest hill in the Otaniemi campus area. The natural forest is used as the altar wall where a cross has been erected directly into the bedrock. Otakappeli Chapel is a globally renowned and awarded architectural site.

properties.name: Otakaari 1
properties.hist: The main building of the former Helsinki University of Technology, designed by Alvar and Elissa Aalto, was completed in 1964. The red bricks of the campus buildings suggest old Finnish industrial architecture.

properties.name: Library
properties.hist: Elissa and Alvar Aalto designed the Otaniemi campus library which was completed in 1969. The library has undergone an extensive renovation and in the autumn of 2016 all Aalto University campus libraries moved under the same roof. The library building is nowadays called Harald Herlin Learning Centre.

properties.name: Saw Building
properties.hist: The saw building designed by Alvar Aalto is the oldest building on campus, completed in 1955. The saw served the Helsinki University of Technology campus during the construction period in the 1950s and 1960s, and was later used to train students from the Department of Forest Products Technology. Currently the Saw Building functions as a venue for various events.

properties.name: Otahalli
properties.hist: Otahalli Sports Centre, designed by Alvar Aalto, was completed for the 1952 Olympics. Otaniemi’s sports centre boasts a grassy field, grounds for track and field, a skating area, two street basketball courts, three tennis courts and a jogging track.

properties.name: Jämeräntaival 1
properties.hist: This building, completed in 1966, is the only dormitory on campus designed by Alvar Aalto. Originally it functioned during the summers as a hotel and served as accommodation in the 1952 Olympics and in 2005 World Championships.

properties.name: Dipoli
properties.hist: The Student Union building was completed in 1966. The materials of the structure, which represent organic architecture, derive from Finnish nature: pine, copper and natural stone.

properties.name: Teknologföreningen
properties.hist: The Swedish speakers’ sorority house, part of the former Helsinki University of Technology was completed in 1966. Club TF – the first disco in the region of Finland’s capital – functioned in the premises, and since the 1980s the tradition has been continued by the Täffä AB restaurant.

properties.name: Teekkari Village
properties.hist: Teekkari Village was planned and designed by Heikki Siren and Matti Melakari. The first stage of the village was completed for the 1952 Olympics. The construction of these buildings represents the world’s largest stunt ever performed by students: engineering students helped onsite to clear and move, in a voluntary work project, a total of 800,000 bricks from the Soviet Embassy, which had been bombed and destroyed during the Continuation War.

properties.name: Servin Mökki
properties.hist: Kaija and Heikki Siren designed this students’ restaurant, which was completed in the centre of the Teekkari Village in 1952. The original Servin Maijan mökki has evidently been a recreational facility in Helsinki’s Alppila district.

properties.name: Polytechnical Students' Museum
properties.hist: Wish to see the funniest and cleverest moments in polytechnic history in Otaniemi? Visit Polytechnical Students' Museum provide by the polytechnic students! You have the opportunity to explore polytechnic symbols, life and activities. Also, if you have ever wondered what are the most legendary tricks pulled by the polytechnic students, look no further!

properties.name: Laajalahti's Natura Area
properties.hist: For the most part Laajalahti Nature Reserve consists of open water. There are also a broad reedbed and shoreline groves and meadows. It is an important area for the plentiful nesting population in the region and for the thousands of birds which stop there during spring and autumn migration in April-May and August-September. The aim of the nature reserve is to conserve the shallow sea water bay and its surrounding area and for the area to possibly be used for outdoor recreation. The area's landscape is maintained by using meadows as pastures for livestock. Visitors can enjoy the area's landscape and wildlife from its bird watching towers and trails without disturbing them.

properties.name: Ancient Grave
properties.hist: The grave is over 3000 years old and is located in front of Jämeräntaival 3. It reminds of the humans history in the area. It was thought that the grave belongs to the fishermen who were the first people in the Otaniemi area.

properties.name: Haglunds Estate
properties.hist: Clas Johan von Numers built the country house in the beginning of 1800.

properties.name: History Photo
properties.hist: 80 years ago if you lifted your head up and looked towards the main building of Aalto University, this is what you would have seen! The Mansion of Otaniemi can be seen in the back in all its glory.

properties.name: History Photo
properties.hist: Mansion of Otaniemi, depicted in year 1957. Few years before the building was taken down. Today you can find the main building of Aalto University in its place.

properties.name: Burning of Otaniemi
properties.hist: In 1577 Tallinn was surrounded by Ivan the Terrible and Tartars. Tartars travelled from Estonia to Finland as a part of the war. Over 1200 Tartars attacked to west in Finnish coast line and Otaniemi was one of the cities which were burned in winter 1577.

properties.name: First school in Otaniemi
properties.hist: The first school in Otaniemi was started in 1878. Anna Sinebrychoff was the person who had taught (reading, religion, history, geography etc.) children in the area since 1862. When the school was started in 1878, the language was Swedish.
